awd_abstract_narration:
Abstract Title: An Approach for Area Efficient Ultra-Broadband Low Power mmWave Beamforming Transceivers in Communication and Medical Applications

Jacques C. Rudell, University of Washington
Proposal NO: 1454098 (Career)


Broadband wireless internet access has been identified by the Federal Communications Commission as a foundational necessity for "economic growth, job creation, global competitiveness, and a better way of life". Existing consumer electronic devices heavily utilize the spectrum around the Very High Frequency (VHF) microwave bands (300MHz 5 GHz) for radio communication; however, with the proliferation of mobile smart phones, notebook, and laptop computers, the microwave band has become increasingly crowded. In contrast, the spectrum available above 24 GHz, commonly referred to as the millimeter wave (mmWave) band, is sparsely occupied and presents opportunities to address future wireless infrastructure demands. Exploiting these higher frequency bands requires new strategies to realize small, low-cost, broad bandwidth, and low power hardware. Although significant research effort over the past decade has been applied toward the realization of practical mmWave hardware solutions, the devices developed thus far have yet to experience widespread adoption, due in large part to the increased complexity associated with operating at such high frequencies. This research seeks to not only improve upon the existing hardware technology, but to transform it with new radio architectural techniques. In addition to expanding consumer markets, these hardware solutions will also benefit other areas, such as scientific and medical research; examples include improvements to Positron Emission Tomography (PET) imaging systems and transceivers for 5th Generation (5G) mobile devices. Moreover, these system and circuit challenges will also provide an ideal backdrop for integrating this research with University coursework, helping to prepare students for careers in industry and academia.
This research seeks to address broad challenges inherent to realizing extremely wideband mmWave systems: What are the fundamental hardware trade-offs between power consumption, silicon area, and complexity for energy efficient longer-range mmWave communication These tradeoffs will be explored in this research using experiments to develop mmWave circuits and systems which demonstrate reliable, long range, broad bandwidth wireless communication in bands above 24GHz. Specific research objectives include: (1) invent and define new circuit topologies to facilitate integration of high-element low power phased-array transceivers, (2) develop techniques to build ultra-broadband circuits using minimal silicon area in conventional low cost silicon CMOS, and (3) design low power frequency synthesizers and the associated local oscillator distribution networks for high-element phased-array systems with minimal power consumption. The PI is actively involved in the IEEE and has strong relationships with many industry partners including Qualcomm, Broadcom, Google, Boeing, and Intel Corp. This places him in a unique position to disseminate research findings and new design methodologies to a wide audience through seminars and workshops for private industry, and at international conferences.

por.por_cntn:
The Federal Communications Commission has recognized that broadband access is a critical infrastructure and a foundational necessity for "economic growth, job creation, global competitiveness, and a better way of life." While the millimeter wave spectrum available above 24 GHz presents opportunities to address the future demand for wireless infrastructure, exploiting these higher frequency bands requires new strategies to realize hardware solutions which are small, low-cost, broad bandwidth, and low power. The research conducted under this CAREER award explored analog, mixed-signal and digital wireless transceiver circuits and architecture, which are amenable to integration in high-volume, low-cost, advanced complimentary metal oxide semiconductor (CMOS) technologies. Fundamental hardware trade-offs between power consumption, ultra-broad bandwidth and silicon area were explicit goals of the research conducted under this CAREER award over the last five years. Beyond the technical achievements associated with this project, resources granted by this award were used to either partially, or exclusively fund six PhD students. Critical to the U.S. remaining a leader in the semiconductor industry is the ability to recruit and train young engineers in all aspects of chip design and fabrication. Of the six PhD students involved with this project, three have completed their PhDs and launched their CAREERS in IC design at Apple, Boeing, and Google, while three more students are continuing to pursue their PhD degrees with a research emphasis on millimeter-Wave (mm-Wave) circuits and systems.

Future 5th and 6th Generation (5G and 6G) wireless networks must address the ever-increasing demand for more network capacity and higher data rates. The available spectrum in the millimeter mm-Wave bands present an opportunity to address the future high-data rate demands. However, the high-signal path loss in the mm-Wave band demands new methods to allow long-range wireless communication. Multiple Input Multiple Output (MIMO) phased-arrays systems are a tool to help overcome the traditional challenges associated with high-path loss in the mm-Wave band, by utilizing an array (phased-array) of radios (elements) which are correlated in their signal transmission and reception, to improve the overall data throughput. The throughput of a MIMO transceiver is proportional to the number of elements used to realize the phased-array. Therefore, finding low-cost technologies to miniaturization the transceiver elements becomes paramount to realizing "massively" arrayed MIMO systems. The research conducted under this CAREER award explored methods to increase the instantaneous bandwidth while reducing the silicon footprint occupied by these receiver elements integrated in a low-cost, advanced silicon-CMOS chip technology.

Several prototype chips were implemented during the period of this project to demonstrate some of the aforementioned concepts with respect to miniaturization, cost in high-volume manufacturing and enhanced bandwidths. During the early phase of this project, two prototype receiver building blocks demonstrated more than 20 GHz of instantaneous bandwidth using a 40nm CMOS technology to fabricate the chip. A second chip was implemented in 28nm CMOS technology, to demonstrate a novel method to generate quadrature signals which form the backbone of modern communication systems, allowing complex signal modulation to communicate information. This prototype device demonstrated a phase accuracy better than 2o and gain imbalance of less than 0.32dB from 55-to-70 GHz.  The last two prototype chips implemented 4-element phased-array receivers in a 28nm CMOS technology and demonstrated the use of a Gm-assisted matching network to improve the noise figure of a 20 GHz bandwidth mixer-first receiver. The second receiver of the last two chips on this project, implemented a digital multi-beam receiver with a variable dynamic range analog-to-digital converter and a noise cancellation architecture. The device has the capability to form multiple spatial beams which holds promise to further enhance network capacity by communicating with multiple users. All the designs and prototype devices were made available to our industrial partners, in addition to numerous public presentations and publications in freely available conferences and journals.
